title: Rock 'n' Roll High School
plot_outline: A group of rock-music-loving students, with the help of the Ramones, take over their school to combat its newly installed oppressive administration.
keywords: [u'ramones', u'high-school', u"rock-'n'-roll", u'teenager', u'mouse', u'exploding-animal', u'drive-in-classic', u'reference-to-led-zeppelin', u'absurd-humor', u'spoof', u'camp', u'low-budget-film', u'teen-movie', u'bong', u'school-principal', u'juvenile-delinquent', u'b-movie', u'punk-rock-girl', u'hall-monitor', u'gym-class', u'cult-film', u'punk', u'punk-rock', u'psychotronic', u'rebellion', u'independent-film']
taglines: [u"Hey ho, Let's go!", u'Will your school be NEXT?', u"Where the 3 R's Stood for ROCK, ROLL and REBELLION!"]
trivia: [u'The Ramones were paid a total of $25,000 for appearing in the film, and had to play shows in southern California to help pay their hotel bills. During the 21-day shoot, Dee Dee Ramone got arrested for fighting with a roadie, overdosed in jail, and wound up in Cedars Sinai Hospital with a $3,000 medical bill.', u'The on screen concert was attended by actual Ramones fans, whose uncontrollable, raucous behavior terrified lead P.J. Soles.', u'Dee Dee Ramone was such a bad actor that his lines were cut from seven down to two, in the dressing room after the concert: "Hey, pizza!" and "Hey, pizza! It\'s great! Let\'s dig in!"', u'Originally, Todd Rundgren was to star as the musical act, but both sides could not come to an agreement. Next, Cheap Trick was contacted, but a similar situation happened. After that, talks were conducted with Warner Bros. Records, where Allan Arkush had a connection, to decide on which band they should use in the film. The first suggestion was Devo, but Arkush decided that they had too much of their own concept. Another band considered for the movie was Van Halen, but Warner execs warned Arkush that they were raucous and would be difficult to handle. Finally, an exec name-dropped the Ramones, who recorded for Sire Records, a subsidiary of Warner Bros. Records. Arkush, being a huge fan of the band, agreed. To this day, Rundgren regrets passing up the role he was offered.', u'P.J. Soles had never heard Ramones before being cast in the film. She was given their music to listen to but she admits that she did not like it initially. But after her enjoyment of working with them, she became a fan of theirs.', u'The high-school was portrayed by the non-operational Mount Carmel High School in South Central Los Angeles which had been closed-down since 1976. The building of the school blown-up at the end is the school which was scheduled for demolition. The explosion was five times bigger than it was supposed to be, and since the filming was at 3am, a lot of frightened neighborhood residents charged out of their homes, not knowing what had happened.', u'When The Ramones are backstage after the concert and Riff gives them her song, in the background on the wall is a picture of Cherie Currie, formerly the lead singer of The Runaways. The Runaways and The Ramones toured together.', u"During The Ramones' concert sequence at The Roxy near the end of the film, Darby Crash, late singer of seminal Los Angeles punk band The Germs, can be seen in the front row.", u'As an inside joke regarding producer Roger Corman\'s notoriously stingy budget on the movie, sounds of birds going "cheap, cheap, cheap" can be heard as the New World Pictures credit appears onscreen.', u'The romantic theme song heard under the credits, "Did We Meet Somewhere Before?" is sung by Paul McCartney and Wings. McCartney wrote it as the theme to Heaven Can Wait (1978), but Warren Beatty decided not to use it. Allan Arkush, the director, then swung a deal whereby he was able to use the song for only $500 provided McCartney did not receive screen credit.', u"P.J. Soles purchased her own wardrobe because the film's budget was so low that they could not afford decent clothes for her. She spent her entire salary, $2100.00, on her clothes. The red satin jacket was $300.00 from Fred Segal. According to Soles, Rod Stewart was at the store and wanted to buy the jacket but she had claimed it before him.", u'The Ramones were recording their "End of the Century" album while working on this film.', u"The song 'Rock 'n' Roll High School' was changed in order to accommodate 'PJ Soles', who was unable to sing the song in its original key.", u'On the last day of shooting, Allan Arkush was hospitalized for exhaustion, and Joe Dante was tapped to direct the remaining scenes, which were the scene in the gym where P.J. Soles sings her version of "Rock \'n\' Roll High School", the long take in the bathroom, and the scene involving the telephone booth.', u'The notoriously cheap Roger Corman, also a publicity genius, invited music journalists to work as extras in return for getting to be on the set and interview the principals.', u'Dick Miller improvised his line "Those Ramones are ugly, ugly people."', u'The "I Want You Around" number was the first scene shot for the film.', u"Hand-written posters visible on the walls during the Ear Mail sequence include a recruiting poster for the People's Temple offering free Kool-Aid and a film club poster advertising a double-feature showing of Death Race 2000 (1975) (directed by Paul Bartel) and Hollywood Boulevard (1976) (directed by Allan Arkushand Joe Dante).", u"The role of Eaglebauer was originally written for Eddie Deezen. However, Deezen was busy working on Steven Spielberg's 1941 (1979), so the role was handed to Clint Howard.", u'The name of the Rock \'n\' Roll High School (1979) was the "Vince Lombardi High School".', u"The origins of the film's plot were seeded in an old favorite story told to co-writer Joseph McBride by his father, the Milwaukee Journal's Raymond E. McBride, who held a walkout at the Central High School in Superior, Wisconsin during the 1920s.", u'The joke license plate number on the Ramones\' car read "GABBA-GABBA HEY".', u'The marijuana that Riff smokes was actually a mix of rosemary and other herbs.', u"The movie's main poster was designed in a similar vogue to the one used for Animal House (1978) a year earlier. That movie had been a box-office hit. Instead of a fraternity house exploding with action and characters, this movie did the same except it was a high school main building instead.", u"The movie spurred just the one sequel which was made and released around twelve years later. Rock 'n' Roll High School Forever (1991) didn't garner theatrical releases and was a straight to video movie debut.", u'Roger Corman\'s original title for the film was "Disco High" until Allan Arkush heard The Ramones and decided to use them in his movie.', u'Allan Arkush tried for several years to get the film produced under various rough draft titles: "High School Spirit of \'76", "Heavy Metal Kids", "Girls\' Gym", "California Girls", and "Disco High". After Todd Rundgren, Cheap Trick and Tom Petty declined the project, Arkush settled on the Ramones for the band in the film.', u'Reportedly, on 31st July 2008, it was announced that Alex Winter had been hired to develop a script to remake this movie for Howard Stern.', u'Banner slogans for the school read "Winning is better than losing" and "Winning isn\'t the most important thing....It\'s the only thing".', u'Mary Woronov, who plays the tyrannical Principal Togar, is only seven years older than P.J. Soles, who plays rebellious high school student Riff Randell.', u'Despite playing a high school student, P.J. Soles was 28 when the movie was filmed, and was actually older than three of the four members of the Ramones (only Johnny Ramone was older than Soles).', u"His role as the School Board President marked the final film performance of 'Grady Sutton', ending a career that spanned almost 55 years.", u'The only ever production where director Joe Dante is billed as a writer.', u'The film takes place in 1980.', u'Among the albums in Riff\'s bedroom that are shown are Bob Dylan\'s "Highway 61 Revisited", The Who\'s "Who\'s Next", The Rolling Stones\' "Sticky Fingers", and The Ramones\' "Road to Ruin".', u'While technically it otherwise has no connection to "Rock \'n\' Roll High School" (and takes place in the 50\'s), actresses PJ Soles, Dey Young, and Mary Woronov reunited for the 1994 remake of "Shake, Rattle, and Rock". The characters they played in that film are named Evelyn Randall, Kate Rambeau Sr., and E. Joyce Togar (respectively).', u'The movie had a number of working titles including "Girl\'s Gym", "Disco High" and "Heavy Metal Kids".', u'Rob Bottin: Uncredited, the special-effects and make-up artist as a giant white mouse / Mrs. Mouse.', u'Joe Dante: Uncredited, the director as a riot cop with sunglasses.', u'Allan Arkush: Uncredited, as a ticket-taker in a green shirt.']
release_dates: [u'USA::4 August 1979 (New York City, New York)', u'USA::24 August 1979', u'Finland::30 November 1990', u'Greece::18 September 2009 (Athens Film Festival)']

However, since this movie was made non-union he had to pay his entire salary as a fine to the Director's Guild.", u'Shot in four weeks.', u"John Sayles' original script ran one hundred thirty pages long.", u"John Sayles' original script had a more diverse array of hit songs from the late 20s and early 30s, but this idea had to be nixed because the budget was too low to pay for the clearance rights to all these songs.", u'This film performed poorly at the box-office. Roger Corman re-released it in 1980 under the title "Guns, Sin, and Bathtub Gin", but it did not fare much better.', u"When Lewis Teague directed Robert Forster in a short second unit scene for Avalanche (1978), two of them decided that if Teague got to direct a full movie, he would offer Forster a role. During his audio commentary, John Sayles reveals that he had originally written an earlier scene, in which Dillinger (Robert Conrad) taught Eddie how to drive a car backwards. But this scene was cut for time and budgetary reasons, and was never shot.', u'The set for the whorehouse was laced with Christmas lights on the ceiling.', u'Robert Forster:']

title: Saint Jack
plot_outline: Jack Flowers, an American hustler in early 1970s Singapore, dreams of building a fortune by running a brothel and returning to the States to lead a life of luxury.
keywords: [u'american-abroad', u'1970s', u'vietnam-war', u'reference-to-fidel-castro', u'reference-to-john-f.-kennedy', u'cia', u'senator', u'brothel', u'ambition', u'friendship', u'blackmail', u'singapore', u'pimp', u'written-and-directed-by-cast-member', u'prostitution', u'independent-film', u'character-name-in-title']
taglines: [u'"People make love for so many crazy reasons-- why shouldn\'t money be one of them?" - The Gospel According To Saint Jack']
trivia: [u'Knowing full well that the Singaporean authorities would never sanction a film that depicted their city as being a hotbed of corruption and sleaze, the script that Peter Bogdanovich submitted to them had been specially rewritten with all the contentious elements removed. Approval was granted. However, when the film was completed, the Singaporean authorities were horrified to see the true nature of the film and subsequently banned it.', u'According to Peter Bogdanovich in his collaborative book "This is Orson Welles", Bogdanovich wanted Welles to direct this film as a comeback for his mentor, and Welles was set to do so, but then, with some pressure from the studio, and his steady girlfriend Cybill Shepard, Bogdanovich ended up directing it himself. This led to a falling-out between the two friends, Bogdanovich and Welles, that wasn\'t completely resolved for nearly a decade, shortly before Welles\'s death.']

And worse... they're still alive!"]
trivia: [u'Future director, then head of publicity and marketing, Jim Wynorski, is the one who came up with the title change and tagline, and did additional filming, in order for this to be known as "Screamers" in the United States.', u'A sequel directed by the same director Sergio Martino was made and released about sixteen years later and entitled The Fishmen and Their Queen (1995) ["The Fishmen and Their Queen"].', u'Actors Mel Ferrer, Jim Alquist, Eunice Bolt, Tom J. Delaney and Cameron Mitchell only appear in the American (US) version of the movie.', u'For the American version B-movie producer Roger Corman had additional footage shot for the opening which runs for around just under twelve minutes with the total amount used for the New World Pictures US version totaling to around fifteen minutes.', u'The movie has often been likened to a cross between H.G. Wells The Island of Dr. Moreau (1977) and the Creature from the Black Lagoon (1954).', u'Second part of director Sergio Martino\'s "Adventure Trilogy" with the first being Viidakon julma salaisuus (1978) ("Mountain of the Cannibal God") and the third The Great Alligator (1979) ("Big Alligator River").', u'The movie has had numerous titles for its English language releases which include "Screamers", "The Fish Men", "Island of Mutations", "Island of the Fishmen", "Something Waits in the Dark", and "The Island of the Fishmen".', u'Barbara Bach was first top-billed in the lead female role in this movie which features the mythological underwater city of "Atlantis". Bach had recently appeared in the James Bond movie The Spy Who Loved Me (1977) which featured a villain\'s underwater lair also called "Atlantis". Even her character names were similar, Amasova in the Bond film, and Amanda in this movie.', u'The movie is set in 1891 five years before H.G. Wells\' novel "The Island of Dr. Moreau" had been first published in 1896 - a story which this movie has been likened to.', u'Cast members Barbara Bach, Richard Johnson and Claudio Cassinelli all returned to star in this film\'s director Sergio Martino\'s The Great Alligator (1979) ("Big Alligator River").', u'The name of the famous underwater mythological city featured in the movie was "Atlantis".', u"One of a cycle of 1980s and mid-late 1970s movies that got made after the box-office success of Jaws (1975). The films include that movie's three sequels, Jaws 2 (1978), Jaws 3-D (1983), and Jaws: The Revenge (1987), as well as Orca (1977), Piranha (1978), Tentacles (1977), Piraijat - raatelijat (1979), Barracuda (1978), Tintorera: Killer Shark (1977), Blood Beach (1980), Piranha Part Two: The Spawning (1981), The Last Shark (1981), Up from the Depths (1979), Humanoids from the Deep (1980), Screamers (1979), Devil Fish (1984) and Mako: The Jaws of Death (1976)."]

taglines: [u'A hideous death lurked unseen in the river...', u'They came downriver in their thousands. Their teeth could strip a living man to the bone in seconds.', u'Lost River Lake was a thriving resort - until they discovered...', u"They're here...Hungry for flesh! Who can stop them?", u"There's something in the water at Lost River Lake. Something you can't see...something you can't feel...until it's too late!", u'Then... you were shocked by the great white shark - Now... you are at the mercy of 1000 jaws!']
trivia: [u'Universal Studios attempted to sue New World for spoofing Jaws (1975). However, Steven Spielberg saw the movie in advance and loved it. After that, Universal dropped the lawsuit.', u'Bradford Dillman was originally unhappy with his character\'s 2D nature, and asked writer John Sayles why his character was so thin. Sayles responded that Roger Corman regularly did not use good actors in his film, so he deliberately didn\'t elaborate on characters. But since Dillman was a "real" actor, he was more than happy to enhance his character\'s depth.', u'The piranha were done by attaching rubber puppet fish to sticks.', u'A waitress from the Holiday Inn where the director and crew were staying stood in for Heather Menzies during the topless shots because Menzies was concerned that her husband might not approve of the nude scene.', u'This film was reported to have been shot in 30 days for $660,000.', u'Executive producer Roger Corman called this film "my homage to Jaws (1975)."', u'The extras were all paid $5 a day and given a box lunch.', u'The score cost $10,000 dollars.', u'The video game that Maggie (Heather Menzies-Urich) is playing toward the beginning of the movie is "Jaws".', u'This movie was one of the first efforts for effects and makeup artists Rob Bottin and Phil Tippett.', u"Barry Brown's last role in a theatrical feature.", u'John Sayles used the profits from the film to fund his own projects. It was also his scriptwriting debut.', u"Barbara Steele's role was originally written for a man.", u'A "bobbing corpse" that appears in the climactic piranha attack was modeled after Rob Bottin.', u'Although implied by the film, the novelization confirms that Paul and Maggie slept together while Hoak is their prisoner.', u"The novelization fills in some of the background about Paul's character. His wife left him which is why he's such a hard drinker. The only explanation given is that she couldn't stand the sight of him. He doesn't write or try to contact his daughter, something Laura the camp councilor resented him for. She later changed her mind about Paul after saving (some of) the kids from piranha. Including his daughter. And the main reason Dumont thinks he's drunk over the phone is because during one visit to the camp, Paul drunkenly threw Dumont in the river when he told him to leave.", u"The novelization also fills in some trivia about Maggie. When her boyfriend just walked out on her, she hired a skip-tracer to find him. She got so hooked on the process she decided to become one herself. By the time she caught up with her ex, she wasn't interested anymore in why he left.", u'Originally, Maggie counted to 300 instead of 100 at the climax. This was probably changed because in all likelihood, Paul would have drowned after being underwater for that long.', u"Piranha (1978) had some documented production problems. There were last-minute cast changes, underwater cameras that kept breaking down, union woes, and unusable second unit footage. It still went on to become one of New World Pictures' biggest hits.", u'The Aquarena Springs and Resort theme park (located in San Marcos Springs in San Marcos, TX), which opened in 1951, was purchased and became the property of Texas State University - San Marcos (formerly Southwest Texas State University). The amusement park ceased operations in 1996 and the facility is known as Aquarena Center (an environmental learning center).', u'Peter Fonda was originally offered the role of Paul Grogan, but turned it down.', u"When the guard at the dam is watching a commercial promoting the resort at Lost River Lake, originally some of Dumont's campers were part of the promotion, but this was cut from the movie. Another scene cut was Dumont accidentally appeared in the background of the commercial, ruining the shot. He was ordered off the premises by Buck Gardener.", u'Rick Baker was originally tapped to provide the make-up effects but recommended the then 17-year-old Rob Bottin instead.', u'Eric Braeden was originally cast as Paul Grogan, but he pulled out to pursue another project. He had already shot some underwater swimming footage which is used in the film.', u'The special effects budget was $50,000.', u'The film was designed to jump on the huge success of Jaws (1975). Roger Corman was known for producing films that were veiled imitations of more successful movies. But it still took a further three years to raise enough money to make the film. By which time Jaws 2 (1978) had already been made.', u"One of a cycle of 1980s and mid-late 1970s movies that got made after the box-office success of Jaws (1975). The films include that movie's three sequels, Jaws 2 (1978), Jaws 3-D (1983), and Jaws: The Revenge (1987), as well as Orca (1977), Piranha (1978), Tentacles (1977), Piraijat - raatelijat (1979), Barracuda (1978), Tintorera: Killer Shark (1977), Blood Beach (1980), Piranha Part Two: The Spawning (1981), The Last Shark (1981), Up from the Depths (1979), Humanoids from the Deep (1980), Screamers (1979), Devil Fish (1984) and Mako: The Jaws of Death (1976).", u'The breed of piranha is Brazilian in the novelization.', u"According to Joe Dante in the DVD commentary originally released in 2004, the noise that the piranhas make underwater are the sounds of dental drills. While he didn't go into anymore detail than that, they could the put the edge of the drills into water and an underwater mic captured the sounds when they were turned on. Another possibility is the drills were turned on above water and recorded from underwater.", u'Steven Spielberg described this film as "the best of the Jaws (1975) rip-offs." He and Joe Dante later collaborated on Twilight Zone: The Movie (1983).', u'In one if the scenes a girl is seen reading Moby Dick, this story is also about a marine animal attacking people.', u'Entertainment Weekly ranked this Number Nine on their "Guilty Pleasures: Testosterone Edition" list in their March 30, 2007 issue.', u"Belinda Balaski's death scene was shot in a pool. Thirty fake piranha were attached to Balaski's body with gaffer's tape and a bunch of crew members pulled her into the deep end of the pool with ropes to make it look like her character was sinking into the water. Moreover, Roger Corman demanded a reshoot of Balaski's death scene because he thought the first version didn't have enough blood in it.", u"In the novelization, Brandy dies as well when she jumps in the water after the piranha to avenge Jack. Since she isn't seen again after Jack's body is found, that scene was probably cut from the film.", u"The boy on the canoe originally didn't emerge unscathed like he does in the film. He suffered severe lacerations on his arms but this doesn't appear in the film. He is however in a state of shock because of his father's death. He even thinks Hoak is his father, which is why he keeps calling him Daddy when Paul and Maggie dump his body overboard."]

taglines: [u"In the year 3000 there'll be no more Olympic Games, World Series, or Superbowl. There'll be only...", u'The Ultimate Ride for Survival', u"DeathSport isn't just a game. In the year 3000, it's the only way to survive!"]
trivia: [u'Tragic fates befell several people involved with the production, Lead actress Claudia Jennings was killed in a car accident shortly after the release of the film, lead actor David Carradine died of accidental asphyxiation in 2008, and director Allan Arkush went on to make Caddyshack II (1988). This has led many to talk of "the curse of \'Deathsport\',"', u'According to co-director Allan Arkush, David Carradine smoked a lot of marijuana while shooting this film.', u'During the preview, at the point where David Carradine\'s character Kaz Oshay says "Now we will have our duel," an audience member was heard to shout out, "It\'s about time!"', u"One of the reasons why Nicholas Niciphor was fired was because he repeatedly clashed with the film's stars, David Carradine and Claudia Jennings. Carradine broke his nose in an on-set altercation.", u"Claudia Jennings was killed in a car crash shortly after the film's release.", u'The cave scenes with the mutants were shot at Bronson Caves in Bronson Canyon. When a stuntman playing a mutant was set on fire, another actor portraying a mutant was also accidentally set on fire.', u'The motorcycles were basically street Yamahas modified with aluminum, which gave them too much weight and made the edges too sharp.', u'In addition to providing the narration, Ron Gans provided voices for just about every character in the film wearing a helmet.', u'At one point, Claudia Jennings had to be physically removed from the set as she was drunk and high on cocaine (she had a well-documented cocaine addiction at the time).', u'A sequel of sorts to Death Race 2000 (1975), the film\'s box-office failure halted plans for a third film that would have been entitled "Deathworld".', u"The opening credits sequence utilizes psychedelic light show effects done by director Allan Arkush with his friend Ben Haller in Arkush's basement in Van Nuys, CA. They were leftovers from Arkush's days creating these sorts of effects to play behind acts in rock concerts.", u'Charles B. Griffith was commissioned as a screenwriter for this project, and came up with three different scripts.', u'Original director Nicholas Niciphor, a.k.a. Henry Suso, was a USC film student who had made some excellent shorts. He had been in an agent\'s office pitching himself in order to get representation, when the agent called Roger Corman. As it turns out, Corman and others at New World had seen and enjoyed Niciphor\'s shorts and Niciphor subsequently got hired to do a re-write for and direct "Deathsport".', u'David Carradine hurt his knee after he leaped against his steel jail cell door.', u'The second nude dance sequence in the film was filmed in jam-and-jelly factory where various lights would get strung up.', u'Nicholas Niciphor had recently graduated from USC when he was hired to co-write and direct the film. He ended up being fired and replaced by Allan Arkush, who later admitted that he had no way of saving the picture. Niciphor is credited under the pseudonym Henry Suso.', u'To this day, Allan Arkush looks back on the film as being his greatest embarrassment.', u'Brenda Venus, who plays Adriann, the mother of the little girl taken by mutants, was in a well-documented relationship with writer Henry Miller at the time. It was well-documented because Venus was in her 20s while Miller was in his 80s.', u'Henry Suso, the pseudonym of co-director Nicholas Niciphor, is taken from the name of a 14th-century German Christian mystic.', u'Pre-production, filming and editing were all completed within six weeks.', u'The film takes place in 3000.']
release_dates: [u'USA::April 1978', u'West Germany::8 September 1978', u'France::13 December 1978', u'Philippines::20 February 1979 (Davao)', u'Turkey::March 1979', u'Denmark::18 June 1980', u'Peru::1982']

Corman said no because he did not want to go over budget.', u'Financed by Roger Corman in exchange for Ron Howard appearing in Eat My Dust (1976).', u'As a promotion for this movie, "16" magazine ran a contest and the winner received a trip to Hollywood and a bit part in the film. Her name was Caryn and she was the girl who catches the bouquet at Paula and Sam\'s wedding.', u'Filmed in only 15 days.', u'All the scenes on the L.A. freeways were shot without permits.', u"Ron Howard's wife Cheryl Howard did the catering on this film.", u"This was Ron Howard's feature directorial debut. title: Fighting Mad
plot_outline: An Arkansas farmer stages a one-man war against corrupt land developers who want to evict him and his neighbors from their farms for real estate developments.
keywords: [u'farmer', u'cult-film', u'man-with-glasses', u'vigilante', u'strip-mining', u'small-town', u'shootout', u'sabotage', u'revenge', u'murder', u'corruption', u'construction-crew', u'bow-and-arrow', u'truck', u'truck-driver']
taglines: [u'The Story Of A Man Who Dares To Stand His Ground-- Until They Blow It Out From Under Him!', u'When You Push Too Far, Even A Peaceful Man Gets Fighting Mad.', u'An Avenger On Wheels...', u'What They Do To His Woman Is The Most Shocking Crime Of All!', u'He Chases Them Across The State And Wipes Them Off The Roads']
trivia: [u'This film was shot in 5-1/2 weeks.', u'Peter Fonda insisted that Bruce Langhorne compose the music for this movie. Fonda also insisted on driving a Caterpillar bulldozer in one scene instead of having a stunt double do it for him.', u"Like many other films, Peter Fonda provided his own artillery for the climatic scene where he infiltrates Crabtree's house.", u'Charles Napier was also considered for the role of Pierce Crabtree.', u'Harry Northup ad-libbed a lot of his own dialogue.', u"The opening montage of scenes featuring Peter Fonda and Gino Franco driving home to Arkansas was shot by Tak Fujimoto, who was originally Jonathan Demme's choice of cinematographer as they worked together in a couple other films prior to this, but being this was a union picture, Fujimoto got caught by the union teamsters and was sent packing back home to California. However, his footage was used for the actual film.", u"[Cameo]: George Armitage. He can be seen as the tennis player who witnesses the murder of Judge O'Connor in the park.", u"To give film editor Anthony Magro some breathing room, Jonathan Demme actually edited the entire climatic sequence where Peter Fonda's character storms Crabtree's property.", u'The jail sequence was filmed on a soundstage in Los Angeles and was the same set used for Jackson County Jail (1976). A body double was used for Gino Franco for this scene.', u'The two goons who worked for Pierce Crabtree were Peter Fain and a hulking guy only known as "cupcake". Apparently, they worked as bodyguards in real-life for Martin Scorsese back in New York and to this day, Jonathan Demme still has no idea how they made it to Arkansas to the filming location.']

title: Moving Violation
plot_outline: A young drifter (Stephen McHattie) and his newly acquired girlfriend (Kay Lenz) witness a corrupt local Sheriff kill his deputy, soon becoming the prime suspects they set off across country to evade capture.
keywords: [u'sheriff', u'small-town', u'car-chase', u'police-shootout', u'police-pursuit', u'police-corruption', u'false-accusation', u'witness', u'on-the-run', u'murder', u'couple', u'female-nudity', u'car-crash', u'independent-film']
taglines: [u"Cam and Eddie have just witnessed a murder ... but there's no one they can tell .. because in this town the cops are the killers!", u"It's A Fender Bending, Body Smashing Demolition Chase That Will Rip Off Your Roof!", u"If you steal it, roll it and wreck it - you're a Moving Violation."]
trivia: [u'This is one of the first movies to feature an airbag being used in a car. General Motors automobiles sold from 1974-76 had the Air Cushion Restraint System which was a regular production option (RPO code AR3) for full size Buick, Oldsmobile, and Cadillac vehicles (the police vehicle seen in the film was a 1974 Oldsmobile Delta 88). This system did not have shoulder harnesses but retained lap belts (the Oldsmobile Toronado of the same era also had a passenger side airbag). The footage of the airbag in use was sent to the U.S. Congress so they could pass a law (the Intermodal Surface Transportation Efficiency Act of 1991) dictating that airbags should be installed in all automobiles manufactured after September 1, 1998. Allstate Insurance provided the Oldsmobile depicted in the film.', u'26 cars are crashed in this film.', u'One stuntman broke his leg after slamming his motorcycle into the back of a car.', u'Even though the movie takes place in Texas, the film was shot entirely in southern California, which explains why palm trees and even the city of Burbank can be seen during the final chase scene.', u"The man portraying H.L. Rockfield's bodyguard was actually one of the union teamster captains.", u"[Cameo]: David R. Osterhout. The film's writer plays the gas station attendant.", u'Producer Julie Corman gave birth to a new baby girl shortly after production wrapped.', u"Because of the film's budget, the producers hired members of an automotive thrill show to serve as the stunt crew.", u'The scene where Eddie goes to the National Guard armory where he procures an M16 assault rifle and a scope - his character is presumably a Vietnam veteran where he shoots up the police vehicles and the sheriff; this particular scene where the police headquarters is under attack was recycled into the script of First Blood.']

taglines: [u'The "Ben-Hur" of Exploitation Movies!', u'The street where starlets are made!', u'Shamelessly loaded with sex and violence.']
trivia: [u'Filmed in ten days in October 1975 for less than $60,000.', u"Dick Miller's character is named for his character in A Bucket of Blood (1959).", u'The plot was inspired by the film The Death Kiss (1932), which directors Joe Dante and Allan Arkush happened to catch on television one night.', u'This movie was shot on short ends. "Short ends" are the parts of film stock that are not processed for developing. If only part of a roll of film is actually used, the developer will only develop the part that was used and leave the unused part in the can. The unexposed parts (the short ends) can then be sold for later use. Low budget productions will often buy these since they are sold at a discount price. This can backfire as there is no way of knowing of the quality of the film, which often explains why a low budget production result in a low quality film.', u'The original title for this film was "Starlets."', u'The mock interviews were all improvised.', u'All the location scenes shot in Hollywood were done without permits.', u'All the scenes at the Gilmore Drive-In Theater were shot in a single evening.', u"Paul Bartel's character Erich Von Leppe is named after the part Boris Karloff's played in The Terror (1963), Baron Victor Frederick Von Leppe. Various scenes from The Terror are seen at the drive-in during Hollywood Boulevard. This also results in an inside joke. While Walter Paisley (who is played by Dick Miller) watches The Terror (which Miller played in), he is essentially watching himself in the movie.", u'WILHELM SCREAM: heard twice during the battle sequence shot in the Philippines.', u"Features many different connections to the film Death Race 2000 (1975) Paul Bartel, the director of that film, and Mary Woronov, one of its stars, are both featured in this movie. Props, vehicles, costumes and even footage from Death Race 2000 are all used in this film. At one point in the story, the star of Hollywood Boulevard Candice Rialson, is seen wearing David Carradine's Frankenstein costume from Death Race 2000.", u'Utilizes footage taken directly two other films. The Big Bird Cage (1972) and Death Race 2000 (1975).', u"The name Patrick Hobby is a reference to F. Scott Fitzgerald's Pat Hobby stories (concerning a hack writer).", u'Rico\'s line, "Is this the end of Rico?" is Edward G. Robinson\'s last line in Little Caesar (1931).', u'Roberta Collins was also considered to play Candy Wednesday.']
release_dates: [u'USA::25 April 1976', u'Netherlands::21 July 1977', u'West Germany::23 March 1978 (TV premiere)', u'Sweden::9 February 1979 (G\xf6teborg Film Festival)', u'Spain::15 October 1980 (Madrid)']

title: Eat My Dust
plot_outline: Darlene's into going fast, Hoover's into Darlene, but when they both get into a red-hot race car, the reckless fun accelerates into a trunk-full of hot pursuits.
keywords: [u'race-car', u'road-movie', u"jack-o'lantern", u'kiss', u'horse', u'checkered-flag', u'purse', u'car-rollover', u'dust', u'sprinkler', u'father-son-relationship', u'dirt-road', u'applying-makeup', u'on-the-run', u'beer-drinking', u'mirror', u'telephone-call', u'sunglasses', u'cigarette-smoking', u'gas-station', u'shower', u'bearded-man', u'shotgun', u'drinking-while-driving', u'farmer', u'police-car', u'bag-of-groceries', u'car-crash', u'trophy', u'dodge-charger', u'blonde', u'race-track', u'announcer', u'dumb-police', u'deputy', u'sheriff', u'drunk-driving', u'one-day', u'olympia-beer', u'chevrolet-camaro', u'budweiser', u'halloween', u'car-chase', u'slapstick', u'coors-beer', u'carsploitation', u'car-movie', u'low-budget-film', u'racing', u'automobile', u'independent-film']
taglines: [u'The greatest car chase ever filmed. See cars, boats, buildings destroyed!', u'A very funny car.', u'The craziest driver in town steals the fastest car in the state, and tears up Puckerbush County!', u'Ron Howard pops the clutch, and tells the world..."EAT MY DUST!"']
trivia: [u'Ron Howard initially turned this part down when he was offered it. He only decided to do it because he was offered a chance to direct another car-chase film for the so-called "Roger Corman Unit" if it was successful. That film would eventually evolve into Grand Theft Auto (1977).', u'Charles B. Griffith came up with the title of the film when the crew were shooting the car chase at the sand dunes. The crew got covered with sand and dirt so much that Griffith turned to Roger Corman and said "We ought to call this picture \'Eat My Dust\'".', u'The movie took 4 weeks to shoot. Ron Howard did all of his scenes in 10 days. A body double drove the car for the rest of the filming.', u"Dave Madden's movie debut.", u'The original title for this film was "The Car."', u"Everything that is Chinese in the movie starts with the name 'Chow'. There is Chow Fongs Family Cafe, Chow Fop's Fresh Fruit, Attorney Chow Lick who represents Mr. Chow Lang in his suit against 'the miscreant' Chow Fong (who is possibly the owner of the aforementioned Cafe).", u'The Puckerbush Union High School that plays at the race course was actually the local band from El Duarte High School. The Puckerbush H.S. motto on the side of the drum is "High Forever" because a Falcon is the El Duarte mascot.', u'Corbin Bernsen in his first named movie role.', u'One of three films picked by Gene Siskel as the worst of 1976.', u'There are 2 drinking games established with this movie. In the first game, a player takes a sip every time they see a pumpkin. In the second game, a player takes a sip every time anyone on screen takes a sip of beer.', u'Three of the Howard family star in the movie. Ron Howard, his father Rance Howard, and his brother Clint Howard.']
release_dates: [u'USA::April 1976', u'West Germany::21 October 1976', u'Sweden::25 December 1976', u'Finland::29 December 1978', u'Denmark::6 February 1981']

taglines: [u"In The Year 2000 Hit And Run Driving Is No Longer A Felony. It's The National Sport!", u'A Cross Country Road Wreck!', u'Across the town the traffic is MURDER']
trivia: [u"Both Sylvester Stallone and David Carradine did much of their own driving. In addition, producer Roger Corman drove in scenes that were shot on public streets, since the custom-built cars used in the movie were not street legal and the film's stunt drivers did not want to be caught driving them by the police.", u'The role of Frankenstein was originally offered to Peter Fonda, who considered the movie too ridiculous for words.', u'Explaining why he took the Frankenstein role, David Carradine says, "I started that picture two weeks after I walked off the Kung Fu (1972) set, and that was essentially my image, the \'Kung Fu\' character, and a lot of people still believe I\'m that guy. The idea actually was: No. 1, if you walk off a television series, you better do a movie right away or you might never get to do one. And the second thing was to do something right away that would create the image of a monster to get rid of the image of that little Chinese guy that I\'d been playing for four years. And, you know, it did kick-start my movie career."', u"The cars didn't run most of the time, so they had to be pushed down hills in order to get them to move. Moreover, the cameras used to film the cars were undercranked in order to perpetuate the illusion that they were moving faster.", u"David Carradine refused to wear leather, so costume designer Jane Ruhm had to make Carradine's iconic black outfit out of another fabric that looked just like leather.", u'According to Roger Corman, several of the custom cars featured in the movie were later sold to car museums for considerably more than it cost to build them.', u"Frankenstein's Alligator car and the Machine Gun car were re-bodied Volkswagens, and Matilda's Buzz Bomb was a VW Karmann-Ghia. The Roman Lion was built on a Fiat 850 Spider chassis. Calamity Jane's Bull was a Corvair. The white Resistance Army car that chases Frankenstein very briefly before crashing and blowing up was a 1965 or 1966 Ford Mustang.", u'Sylvester Stallone wrote some of his own dialogue.', u'Mary Woronov, who plays Calamity Jane, did not know how to drive a car, so a stunt driver did all the actual driving for her in the movie. For close-ups, Woronov sat in a car towed behind a truck with a camera crew riding in it.', u'Roger Corman wrote the original treatment of the film, which was serious in tone, but thought it was not right and, in his words, was "kind of vile". He decided the dark material of the story would be better served by making the movie into a comedy and had Robert Thom rewrite the treatment.', u'The speech mannerisms of the character Harold parody those of Howard Cosell.', u'Carl Bensen plays Harold the announcer in this film and nearly the identical character in another cult classic car chase film, Grand Theft Auto (1977), starring a young Ron Howard.', u'Producer Roger Corman challenged popular YouTube channel CinemaSins to make a sin video on one of his films, this film being the one. CinemaSins is a channel that nitpicks and criticizes many movies for entertainment.', u'The racetrack used for the opening track and grandstand scenes is the Ontario Motor Speedway near Los Angeles.', u'The film retains only the basic premises of the original short story by Ib Melchior; the characters and incidents are all different. The story focuses on just one mechanic and driver, and one anti-racer. In particular, it does not include the President or the special driver Frankenstein.', u"The airplane that attacked Frankenstein's car was Burt Rutan's Vari Viggin.", u'Was theatrically re-released in France in the mid-1980s with its title changed from the literal translation "La Course a la Mort de l\'an 2000" to a more evasive "Les Seigneurs de la Route" (meaning "Lords of the Road"). This time, David Carradine and Sylvester Stallone shared the top billing on the posters.', u"Director Paul Bartel had Jane Ruhm design the opening titles using money from the budget without getting Roger Corman's permission first.", u'The opening sequence was shot at an actual racetrack in between races.', u"Sylvester Stallone 's co-star in the Expendables movies Jason Statham, stars in the remake of this film.", u'Director Paul Bartel passed away in the year 2000, the year the film takes place in.', u'Matilda the Hun\'s "Buzz Bomb" racer features an obvious resemblance to the original Nazi V-1 flying bomb (which the Germans called their "Vengeance Weapon" and which Allied forces nicknamed the "buzz bomb").', u'Sylvester Stallone would again be portraying a race car driver in Driven (2001).', u'The film is set in 2000.', u'Body Count: 33.', u'The car in which President Frankenstein and Annie drive away after their wedding is a Richard Oaks Nova kit-car, actually based on the Volkswagen Beetle chassis (but obviously not the body). These were available in kit form for many years starting in the mid-1970s.']

title: Capone
plot_outline: The story of the rise and fall of the infamous Chicago gangster Al Capone and the control he exhibited over the city during the prohibition years...
keywords: [u'rise-and-fall', u'prohibition', u'gangster', u'true-crime', u'street-shootout', u'kissing-while-having-sex', u'bare-breasts', u'love-interest', u'boyfriend-girlfriend-relationship', u'kiss', u'mistress', u'sex-in-bed', u'sex', u'blood-spatter', u'blood', u'gore', u'gang-brawl', u'blonde', u'gang-war', u'mobster', u'gunfight', u'shootout', u'1930s', u'drive-by-shooting', u'fistfight', u'scarface', u'brawl', u'machine-gun', u"st.-valentine's-day-massacre", u'shoulder-holster', u'pistol', u'car-chase', u'chase', u'violence', u'brutality', u'mob-violence', u'gang-violence', u'trial', u'arrest', u'jail', u'hitman', u'ambush', u'cigarette-smoking', u'cigar-smoking', u'tough-guy', u'villain-played-by-lead-actor', u'vagina', u'erotic-70s', u'female-nudity', u'female-frontal-nudity', u'mafia', u'character-name-in-title']
taglines: [u'From Underworld To Empire', u'The man who made the twenties roar! Now, after 45 years, his true story can be told!']
trivia: [u'Ben Gazzara had dental appliances made to push out his cheeks.', u"Susan Blakely's nude open crotch shot is reportedly one of the first instances of such a thing for a leading actress in a mainstream Hollywood film. It wouldn't be so graphically repeated until Sharon Stone's notorious scene in Basic Instinct (1992) 17 years later.", u"Al Capone got the scar on his left cheek from a knife wound in the Harvard Inn on Coney Island in 1917 over an argument regarding a young lady which he made a comment to. Her brother Frank Gallucio was offended by Capone's remark made to his sister Lena, and demanded an apology.. the end result was Al Capone was slashed three times by Gallucio with a knife thus cutting his face.", u"Writer Howard Browne also wrote The St. Valentine's Day Massacre (1967) (another Capone film) for Roger Corman in 1967. Indeed, footage from that film is recycled here.", u'The film is mainly set in 1929 when Alphonse Capone would have been 30 years old. Ben Gazzara was 45 when he made the film.', u"Ben Gazzara and Harry Guardino were long-time good friends and would spend a lot of their scenes deliberately trying to out act each other for a laugh, much to director Steve Carver's frustration.", u"No mention is made in the film of Capone's wife and children. While the gangster did have several mistresses, he made a point of maintaining a fa\xe7ade of being a decent family man.", u'Shot in four weeks.', u"The final scene was shot at Barbra Streisand's estate in Holmby Hills, California.", u"Timothy Carey was interviewed for a role in this movie, but wasn't cast because he pulled out a .38 caliber pistol, loaded with blanks, on Steve Carver during said interview.", u'According to the Region 1 DVD commentary by Steve Carver, the extras in the prison fight scene enjoyed being beat up by Ben Gazzara.', u'A lot of the violence had to be trimmed to avoid an X rating. Moreover, some of the profanity also had to be toned down in order to secure an R rating.', u'John Cassavetes only worked for one day.', u'Made its first appearance on DVD in the U.S. in 2011.', u"Among the film's many inaccuracies, it features Frank Nitti delivering a eulogy at Capone's funeral. In reality, Nitti died four years before Capone.", u'Susan Blakely did her own stunt falling down on the ground when her character gets shot and killed.']

taglines: [u"It looks like we don't have any Taglines for this title yet."]
trivia: [u'While trying to come up with an ad campaign to this seemingly unmarketable film, New World\'s advertising committee came up with this humorous fake tagline: "He came into town with his cock in hand, and what he did with it was illegal in 49 states."', u'Despite generally positive critical reception, this film was, according to Roger Corman, the only New World Pictures release to lose money.', u"Roger Corman wanted to direct this but in the end, just acted as producer for Monte Hellman. After seeing Hellman's cut, he sent editor Lewis Teague to film extra scenes and got Joe Dante to spice up the trailer.", u'The film has never been released in the UK and was recently banned from public showing at the 2006 Edinburgh Film Festival following intervention by the Scottish Society for the Prevention of Cruelty to Animals (SSPCA). According to the BBFC the movie would never receive a UK certificate as the film contravened the Cinematograph Films (Animals) Act 1937 because the cockfighting scenes were organized for the purpose of filming.']
release_dates: [u'USA::30 July 1974 (Roswell, Georgia)\n (premiere)', u'USA::August 1974', u'Norway::1975', u'Japan::19 January 2013']

taglines: [u'Madder Than Daffy Dumber Than Donald More Existential Than Howard!', u'Any resemblance to ducks living or dead is purely coincidental.', u"Wouldn't YOU Like a Good Duck Tonight?", u'An adult "Cult Classic" that\'s a Quack-Up!']
trivia: [u'The film was not submitted to the MPAA and was never rated. The "X" rating was self-applied by the film\'s distributor as a promotional device.', u'Despite the alternate title, this film has no connection whatsoever with the comic strip character "Dirty Duck", created by Bobby London.', u'The film was being made under the working title "Cheap" because it was a cheap little movie. The final title was "The Down and Dirty Duck", but Roger Corman (whose production company was distributing the film) released it with the short title "Dirty Duck" on all posters and advertisements to cash in on the recent trend of X-rated animated films which started with Fritz the Cat (1972). The title on the film itself was never changed.', u'Had the film been distributed under its original title, "Cheap", the film would have been advertised as "Roger Corman\'s Cheap!" When Corman realized that the title was a shot at his production techniques, he asked that the title be changed.', u'Caricatures of John Lennon, Yoko Ono, and Frank Zappa appear briefly in the film.']
release_dates: [u'USA::July 1974']

taglines: [u'Life made her an outcast. Love made her an outlaw.', u"Bertha Loved Lovin'...But There Was More Money in ROBBIN' TRAINS!", u"Meet Boxcar Bertha...just a little country girl with a talent for lovin', a taste for violence, and a banged-up boxcar for a boudoir.", u"America in the 30's was a Free Country. Bertha was jes' a little bit free'er than most."]
trivia: [u'After he finished this film, Martin Scorsese screened it for John Cassavetes. Cassavetes, after seeing it, hugged Scorsese and said, "Marty, you\'ve just spent a whole year of your life making a piece of shit. It\'s a good picture, but you\'re better than the people who make this kind of movie. Don\'t get hooked into the exploitation market, just try and do something different." Scorsese\'s next film was Mean Streets (1973).', u'David Carradine and Barbara Hershey were a couple at the time of filming.', u'Martin Scorsese personally drew about 500 storyboards for this film', u'The train sequences were shot first and they took about a week. This was done to get the most complicated element of the production, working with a moving train, out of the way first.', u'The Reader Railroad was the actual name of the railroad where the train scenes were filmed. It opened in 1889 and is still in business, used at various times for freight, tourism and movie service. At the time of filming it was still regularly using vintage equipment, most notably steam locomotives.', u"Schedule for the movie was 24 days (according to director Martin Scorsese's commentary for Alice Doesn't Live Here Anymore (1974)).", u'In 1972 American-International Pictures distributed this film on a double bill with Killers Three (1968) starring Robert Walker Jr..', u'There was a rumor that Roger Corman\'s wife Julie Corman obtained the film rights to the story from Bertha Thompson herself after tracking her down in a San Francisco hotel room; she never actually met Thompson--because Thompson wouldn\'t open the door-but that rumor wasn\'t true. It may haver been a pre-release publicity stunt or maybe even a trick played on the Cormans by the true owner of the story, author Ben L. Reitman; the afterword in the fourth re-issue of the book "Boxcar Bertha" explained that the book is a work of fiction, and that the character Bertha Thompson was an amalgam of at least three women that Reitman knew, but was mostly modeled on a woman named Retta Toble.', u'The idea for the film was suggested by Roger Corman as a sort of "sequel" to Bloody Mama (1970), after Martin Scorsese became known for his work on Woodstock (1970).', u'The song \'Big\' Bill Shelley and his guys are singing when Bertha rescues them is an A Capella by Vera Hall, called "Trouble So Hard".', u'There are no characters in the film named Emeric Pressburger or M. Powell, and there are no such actors as Grahame Pratt or "Chicken" Holleman. Director Martin Scorsese added them to the cast list as a tribute to filmmakers Michael Powell and Emeric Pressburger.', u'Barbara Hershey later called the film "a lot of fun even though it\'s terribly crippled by Roger Corman and the violence and sex. But between the actors and Martin Scorsese the director, we had a lot of fun. We really had characters down but one tends to not see all that, because you end up seeing all the blood and sex."', u'The first time that Victor Argo worked with director Martin Scorsese.', u'Martin Scorsese: as a john who is just finishing dressing himself when he asks Bertha if he can spend the night.']

trivia: [u'Director Jack Hill named the sadistic prison warden "Dietrich" after German producer Erwin C. Dietrich, with whom Hill had had a very unpleasant experience after Dietrich hired him to shoot a film in Switzerland.', u'Kathryn Loder had to be hospitalized after becoming seriously ill during the shooting of this film. Loder slipped into a coma while being treated at the hospital and almost died. Fortunately, the doctors discovered that Loder had diabetes and gave her insulin treatment which enabled her to make a complete recovery.', u'None of the extras were told they were going to be squirted with fire hoses during the filming of the cafeteria food fight set piece.', u'Sid Haig helped coach Pam Grier with her acting.', u'In the sequence in which Judith Brown is tortured by having a snake dangled over her head, only a pane of glass separated Brown from said snake.', u'Jack Hill added a dance scene for Brooke Mills to perform in the movie after he found out that Mills was an experienced ballet dancer.', u"Pam Grier's first big acting role.", u'A graphic lesbian scene was shot, but cut from the final finished version of the film.', u'A Filipino porn actress was originally cast as Ferina, but left after the first day of shooting.', u'Roberta Collins\' infamous "Get it up or I\'ll cut it off" line was improvised on the spot by director Jack Hill.', u'Kathryn Loder refused to pick up a cobra snake in one scene, so the animal wrangler had to pick up the snake instead.']

trivia: [u'Robert De Niro lost approximately 30 pounds to play his role.', u'Shelley Winters was such an extreme method actress that she spent the entire evening before the grave scene at a funeral parlor staring at a real corpse in a coffin convincing herself she was staring at her dead son, in addition to listening to loud opera just before shooting a scene to work herself up emotionally, and throwing a very real wine bottle at Lloyd (Robert De Niro) in order to make him cry.', u'In one scene where Herman Barker (Don Stroud) punches Ma Barker (Shelley Winters) in the nose, Stroud accidentally punched Winters in the nose for real, and hurt her badly enough that she had to be taken to the hospital.', u"Bruce Dern's character of Dirkman is a combination of several Barker Gang members, most notably Alvin Carpis, who was a cellmate of Freddie Barker and the primary member of the gang (outside of the family).", u'Shelley Winters previously played a character that spoofed "Ma" Barker. On the TV series Batman (1966), she played "Ma" PARKER in a couple of episodes as a guest star.', u'Robert De Niro arrived in Arkansas a week prior to shooting so he could learn all about the local culture.', u'In a January 2003 interview with Esquire Magazine, Robert De Niro says he spent a lunch break sleeping in an open grave to help stay in character.', u'American International Pictures originally wanted Roger Corman to shoot this film on the MGM studio back lot.', u'A scene with Shelley Winters giving birth was filmed, but cut from the movie. However, a clip from said deleted scene can still be seen in the theatrical trailer.', u'Shelley Winters confesses in her biography that Bpb De Niro insisted to be truly buried, and not a stunt, during the burial in the ground sequence.']

title: Voyage to the Planet of Prehistoric Women
plot_outline: Astronauts landing on Venus encounter dangerous creatures and almost meet some sexy Venusian women who like to sun-bathe in hip-hugging skin-tight pants and seashell brassieres.
keywords: [u'psychotronic-film', u'astronaut', u'rocket', u'space-station', u'robot', u'alien', u'outer-space', u'amazon-tribe', u'volcano', u'venus-the-planet', u'spacesuit', u'space-exploration', u'ruins', u'pterodactyl', u'lizard-monster', u'lava', u'cave', u'independent-film', u'remake']

trivia: [u'This is actually a re-edited version of a film previously released in the U.S. as Voyage to the Prehistoric Planet (1965), which itself was an edited and dubbed version of the Soviet film Planeta bur (1962). For this version the already dubbed Russian footage was re-used but the American insert shots of Basil Rathbone and Faith Domergue were removed and new insert shots featuring Mamie Van Doren and other actresses (as inhabitants of Venus) were inserted. Director Peter Bogdanovich did the narration as if he were one of the cosmonauts telling the story in flashback. Some additional special effects shots from another Soviet production, The Sky Calls (1959), were also added. For this version, the famous shot of the Venusian reflected in the pool of water was removed.', u'Director "Derek Thomas" is actually Peter Bogdanovich.', u'The "Prehistoric Women" do not appear in the original Russian film from which this was made.', u'The film takes place in 1998.']

title: Targets
plot_outline: An elderly horror film star, while making a personal appearance at a drive-in theatre, confronts a psychotic Vietnam War veteran who has turned into a mass-murdering sniper.
keywords: [u'drive-in', u'gun', u'rifle', u'sniper', u'serial-killer', u'spree-killing', u'spree-killer', u'weirdo', u'psycho', u'psychotronic', u'drive-in-classic', u'gun-shop', u'cult-film', u'long-range-rifle', u'written-and-directed-by-cast-member', u'dead-woman-on-bed', u'murder-spree', u'husband-murders-wife', u'view-through-rifle-scope', u'crosshair', u'shot-in-the-back', u'dead-woman-on-ground', u'dead-woman-on-floor', u'dead-woman-carried', u'shot-in-the-stomach', u'shooting-a-woman', u'dragging-a-dead-body', u'random-killing', u'midnight-movie', u'telephone-booth', u'retirement', u'psycho-killer', u'projectionist', u'high-powered-rifle', u'fading-star', u'uxoricide', u'murder-of-a-child', u'matricide', u'mass-murderer', u'delivery-boy', u'cane', u'filmmaking', u'film-star', u'independent-film']
taglines: [u'TARGETS are people...and you could be one of them!', u'Why Gun Control?', u'"I just killed my wife and my mother. I know they\'ll get me. But before that, many more will die..."']
trivia: [u'By the time this film was made (November-December 1967), 80-year-old Boris Karloff was in very poor health with emphysema along with rheumatoid arthritis, and had only one-half of one lung left and spent the time between takes in a wheelchair with an oxygen mask on. He also had braces on both legs, and had difficulty standing or walking without his cane; the weakness of his legs is visible in some scenes. Fortunately, Karloff lived long enough to view the completed film as well as enjoy the accolades he deserved for his performance.', u'Roger Corman told Peter Bogdanovich he could make any film he wanted to, with two conditions: he had to use stock footage from The Terror (1963), and he had to hire Boris Karloff for two days (Karloff was under contract and owed Corman those two days). Karloff was so impressed with the script that he refused pay for any shooting time over his contracted two days. He worked for a total of five days on the movie.', u'The sequence with Bobby Thompson shooting people in cars driving on a freeway from the top of an oil storage tank was loosely inspired by the Highway 101 sniper attack where on April 25, 1965, a 16-year-old alienated youth, named Michael Andrew Clark, shot at motorists from a hilltop along Highway 101 just south of Orcutt, California, killing three and injuring 10 others before committing suicide. Prior to the shooting spree, Clark left behind a note vowing to make his parents "die a thousand times in court" for his actions, and he was right; a lawsuit was brought against Clark\'s parents by two of the victim\'s families for mistreating and not raising their son well, and negligence for allowing Clark access to the hunting rifle used for the shooting spree.', u'The story Orlok tells of the servant fleeing death is W. Somerset Maugham\'s short story "The Appointment in Samarra." Reportedly, Karloff nailed the telling of the story in a single take, and received a standing ovation from everyone on set.', u'Peter Bogdanovich planned to have Boris Karloff actually appear in the film for about 20 minutes with two days of filming, and have the stock footage from The Terror (1963) add another 20 minutes of screen time for Karloff. In the final movie, Karloff is actually on screen (not counting the scenes from "The Terror") for about 30 minutes and shot all his scenes in five days.', u'Aside from background music played on a car radio, there is no musical soundtrack for the movie.', u'The shooter can be heard taking a breath and holding it before each shot when he fires. This is the correct way for a sniper to steady his weapon before pulling the trigger. But when he fires shots at the moving vehicles on the freeway, the crosshairs are centered on the driver or the passenger - which would cause the shooter to miss, because he\'s not "leading" his rapidly moving targets. However, director Peter Bogdanovich did this because audiences would not understand why the shooter was aiming well ahead of each vehicle before he fired. They would expect all his shots to miss if the shooter had done this.', u"The house in which Tim O'Kelly's clean-cut character lives with his happy family is given a fantasy look by the cartoonish colors of the walls in each room, and the strange lack of doorknobs on many interior doors. The sparse wall decorations and the smallness of the rooms gives the house a claustrophobic look. Director Peter Bogdanovich did all this to reflect the warped fairy-tale nature of the deranged young shooter's life.", u"Voices of Joey Bishop and announcer Regis Philbin can be heard in background, excerpted from Bishop's late night ABC TV talk show of late Sixties.", u"The sets for Bobby Thompson's home and for Orlok's hotel room are the same set pieces, with some redressing and a new paint job.", u'As the film includes extracts from Roger Corman\'s film "The Terror", Corman suggested to Peter Bogdanovich that the little-known actor who appears opposite Boris Karloff in that film should also appear in this one, perhaps in the role of the killer. Bogdanovich turned down this idea. The young actor became world-famous shortly after "Targets" first appeared - it was Jack Nicholson.', u"Frank Marshall's parents and then-girlfriend appear as film-goers at the drive-in scenes. The film's dolly grip also appears, as the father shot, to the horror of his son who is sitting next to him in one of the cars.", u'Drive-in scenes were shot at the since-closed Reseda Drive-In Theatre in Reseda, CA, as clearly shown on the marquee and screen tower. Early in the movie, the Sepulveda Drive-In in Van Nuys is briefly shown in the background as Bobby drives down the highway. On the DVD commentary, Peter Bogdanovich incorrectly credits this as being the Reseda Drive-In.', u'Peter Bogdanovich named his own character "Sammy Michaels" after Samuel Fuller (whose middle name is "Michael") in gratitude for the work Fuller did on the script.', u'Shot in 22 days and completed in December 1967 (copyright 1967). Due to its controversial nature, Paramount only released it after inserting a written prologue denouncing gun violence.', u"According to Peter Bogdanovich's introduction to the film on the DVD, the scene in which Sammy wakes up with a hangover and is jolted when the first thing he sees is Byron Orlok originally called for him to laugh at himself, but he couldn't manage it. Boris Karloff suggested the bit that is actually used in the film - and ad-libbed Orlok's start when he unexpectedly confronts himself in a mirror, as well.", u'The sniping scene at the oil tank was shot without a sound technician. All the noises were added in post.', u"When film cameras, which run at 24 frames per second, film directly off the screen of US televisions, which run at 30 fps, the result is a dark or light bar across the image, rolling from top to bottom. To avoid this effect in the scene when Sammy and Orlok are watching The Criminal Code (1931), in most shots a film picture was matted in over the TV screen, giving a steady picture with no bar. However, according to Peter Bogdanovich's DVD commentary, they couldn't afford to use a matte for the establishing shot for the scene, which pans across the TV's screen, so the bar appears in that shot and only that shot (in Europe, where the TV frame rate is 25 fps, often they simply run the film camera at 25 fps also, for shots with a TV picture in them).", u'Although the character of Byron Orlock is based on the man who plays him (Boris Karloff), the similarities are very few. Both are respected and iconic British actors known for their roles in horror films, but while Orlock is embittered with the film industry and wants to retire, Karloff never retired and was always grateful for his success in the film industry. Also, while Orlock seems regretful of his status as a "horror actor," Karloff was in fact very proud of his legacy, and was particularly proud of his most famous role, Frankenstein\'s monster.', u'When Bobby writes out the check to buy the sniper rifle, he writes the check out to Boris Karloff.', u"When Roger Corman hired Bogdanovich to direct, Corman asked if Bogdanovich was familiar with the directorial styles of Alfred Hitchcock and Howard Hawks with Hitchcock's work being very concise, efficient and organized while Hawks opted for a more kinetic shooting style that was partly improvised without much organization. Corman advised Bogdanovich to shoot like Hitchcock.", u'In the beginning credits of the movie, it states, "Radio music supplied by Charles Greene and Brian Stone". The music that they used was "Green Rocky Road", performed by the band "The Daily Flash", which Greene and Stone managed.', u"Samuel Fuller advised Peter Bogdanovich to save as much money as possible, in order to have the film's climax be as epic as it could be.", u'Was edited into a GP rated version and re-released in 1971 in order to capitalize on the popularity of The Last Picture Show (1971)', u'Included among the "1001 Movies You Must See Before You Die", edited by Steven Schneider.', u'(at around 50 mins) The horror story which Orlok (Boris Karloff) tells directly to the audience in his distinctive voice - about a man in ancient times who flees to another city because he believes Death is planning to take him at a certain time and place - is similar to the wonderful stories by mystery writer Michael Avallone for a 1950s radio program called "The Frightened". Karloff\'s powerful delivery of the stories were accompanied by chilling background music and sound effects (including screams, gasps, and terrified pleas for help). In the early 1960s, Mercury Records released thirteen of the stories on two albums entitled "Tales of the Frightened" (volume 1 and 2). They can be heard at Archive.org. Karloff also recorded an album called "Tales of Mystery and Imagination", which includes The Legend of Sleepy Hollow.']
release_dates: [u'Italy::June 1968 (Pesaro Film Festival)', u'USA::13 August 1968 (New York City, New York)\n (premiere)', u'USA::15 August 1968', u'Sweden::15 October 1969', u'Denmark::13 March 1970', u'France::31 March 1971', u'West Germany::20 November 1972 (TV premiere)', u'Spain::29 May 1974 (re-release)', u'Greece::14 April 2004 (DVD premiere)']

taglines: [u'A Lovely Sort of Death', u'Groovy Gravy!...The Trip is Out of Sight!', u'Listen to the sound of love. Feel purple. Taste green. Touch the scream that crawls up the wall!', u'A big thrill in a little pill.']
trivia: [u'In order to prepare for the film, Peter Fonda, Dennis Hopper and Jack Nicholson all engaged in a group LSD trip.', u'Roger Corman also took LSD before starting the film, figuring he couldn\'t make a film about LSD without trying it himself. He had a good experience, and had to ask others what a "bad trip" was like in order to incorporate it into the film.', u'The film was rejected for a UK certificate 4 times by the BBFC (in 1967, 1971, 1980 and 1988) as it was considered an advertisement for the use of LSD. The film was shown uncut on the FilmFour satellite channel in 2002 and finally given a fully uncut UK DVD certificate in January 2004, almost 37 years after its first BBFC submission.', u'Jack Nicholson wrote this screenplay for Corman based on his own experience of taking LSD under controlled laboratory conditions and also on his marriage break-up with first wife, Sandra Knight.', u'Bruce Dern wanted nothing to do with the drug culture, and had to ask director Roger Corman what LSD was in order to prepare for his role.', u'The band in the club near the beginning is the International Submarine Band, featuring Gram Parsons on vocals. However, their early country-rock sounds were removed and the psychedelic sounds of The Electric Flag were dubbed into the film.', u'According to Bruce Dern, Jack Nicholson wrote the part of John for himself. Roger Corman, however, would not agree to Nicholson playing the role and chose Dern instead.', u'Bruce Dern\'s line "Turn off your mind, relax, and float downstream" is from The Beatles\' song "Tomorrow Never Knows", which John Lennon wrote as a summation of his reading of "The Psychedelic Experience", which in turn was adapted from "The Tibetan Book of the Dead".', u'Only American film to be invited to the Cannes Film Festival in 1967.', u'Some of the music was provided by the group The Electric Flag.', u'According to Peter Fonda, he got visibly aroused while filming his nude scene with Salli Sachse. "Salli just clamped her legs together to keep it out of sight," Fonda said, and that director Roger Corman continued to film regardless.']

title: The St. Valentine's Day Massacre
plot_outline: Al Capone's Valentine Day surprise for the rival Bugs Moran gang in 1929 Chicago.
keywords: [u"valentine's-day", u'true-crime', u'death', u'year-1929', u'street-shootout', u'gunfight', u'shootout', u'gun-violence', u'crime-boss', u'bootlegger', u'murder', u'police-officer', u'shoulder-holster', u'ambush', u'1930s', u'villain-played-by-lead-actor', u'cold-blooded-killer', u'hitman', u'drive-by-shooting', u'shotgun', u'pistol', u'suspense', u'gang-violence', u'mobster', u'gang-war', u'shooting', u'brawl', u'fistfight', u'street-fight', u'neo-noir', u'historic-figure', u'winter', u'tommy-gun', u'stealing-car', u'snow', u'narration', u'mob', u'mafia', u'impersonating-a-police-officer', u'chicago-illinois', u'bootlegging', u'stabbed-in-the-ear', u'gangster', u'cult-film']
taglines: [u"They don't negotiate. They eliminate.", u"A warning! This motion picture depicts without flinching the most shocking event of America's most lawless era... The St. Valentine's Day Massacre!", u'The shocking truth about events leading up to one of the most violent days in American history!']
trivia: [u'For the massacre scene in the garage, the actors playing the slain gangsters were shown photos and directed as how to fall so their positions were identical to the real photos of the massacre. Two actors bumped together on the way down. After studying photographs they realized they had fallen and collided in the exact way the slain gangsters had fallen and had landed in the correct positions.', u'Orson Welles was originally picked by director Roger Corman to play Al Capone, while Jason Robards was to play George Moran ("Bugs" Moran). Welles was willing, but Fox vetoed the deal, feeling Welles was "undirectable". Robards took over the role of Capone and Ralph Meeker was brought in to play Moran.', u"Jack Nicholson was to play Bruce Dern's character, Johnny May, but instead shows up in a bit part as a henchman, Gino, loading garlic-soaked bullets into a Tommy gun (Nicholson was still paid for all seven weeks of the shoot.)", u'More squib charges were used in this film than in the three-hour war epic The Longest Day (1962).', u'At the beginning of the movie when Peter Gusenberg (George Segal) asks the barkeep where he\'s getting his beer from, the barkeep answers, "A fellow named Slausen", to which Gusenberg replies, "Slausen? The only Slausen I know works for Caponi, Al Caponi." Believe it or not, Gusenberg\'s pronunciation of Al Capone\'s name is in fact a source of debate amongst historians. Though he\'s known as "Capone" with an "E", early arrest sheets and Chicago Tribune articles listed Capone\'s name as "Caponi" with an "I". However, the Chicago Tribune was known at the time for their blatant spelling errors (like "clew" for "clue") and may be responsible for this misconception of Capone\'s name.', u"This was Roger Corman's first directorial project for one of the major studios (Twentieth Century-Fox). After approximately 15 years experience as a producer/director of low budget productions, it was no surprise that Corman wrapped this production ahead of schedule and well under budget.", u'The real garage where the massacre took place (2122 N. Clark St, Chicago) was torn down three months after the movie was released.', u'Final film appearance for Jean Hale.', u'When "Bugs" Moran is leaving his hotel, just before the massacre, the clerk stops him and says "You have a call from a Mr. Bernstein in Detroit". "Bernstein" was the last name of the four brothers - Abe, Joe, Ray and Izzy - who ran Detroit\'s murderous "Purple Gang". The real George Moran and Al Capone used the Bernsteins to hijack other gangsters\' liquor shipments from Canada. This fact is evident later when Moran complains to his bodyguards about Bernstein jacking up the price.', u"The film came in at $200,000 under budget because Roger Corman reused sets from other movies, including a mansion that served as Capone's home (even though in reality Al Capone lived in a modest brick home in a working-class neighborhood).", u"The set used as a brothel also served the same function in Fox's The Sand Pebbles (1966)", u'Average Shot Length = ~9.2 seconds. Median Shot Length = ~8.4 seconds.', u'Leading lady Jean Hale does not appear until the 47 minute mark.', u'Roger Corman\'s "first big studio film" according to show-business trade paper \'Variety\'.', u'The movie\'s mostly historical accuracy also includes some of the real words spoken by those involved in the massacre. Frank Guesenberg\'s dying answer to the police officer\'s inquiry really was, "Nobody shot me. Leave me alone". George Moran really did exclaim to a reporter, "Only Al Capone kills like that." Capone responded to the press: "Only Moran kills like that. I mean, they don\'t call that guy \'Bugs\' for nothing!"', u'Although most of the facts in the film are close to the truth, the only real deviation concerns the fate of Joe Aiello. While the movie does accurately portray Aiello aligning himself with George Moran and conspiring to kill Mafia chieftain Pasqualino "Patsy" Lolordo, he was not killed personally by Al Capone on a train (though Capone was known to kill when seized by a fit of personal rage). As shown in the film, Aiello, knowing he was marked for death by Capone, did arrange to have a cousin purchase a train ticket for him at the last minute so that he could skip town. However, he was killed by machine gunners from an apartment window opposite his apartment building as he was leaving to catch the train on October 23rd, 1930: A year and nine months after the massacre, not before.']

Their God is hate...', u'The most terrifying film of your time!']
trivia: [u'The Hells Angels brought a $5-million defamation lawsuit against Roger Corman for what they perceived as a negative portrayal of their image.', u"Roger Corman actually used several members of the real Hell's Angels as extras.", u'George Chakiris was originally hired by Roger Corman to play "Black Jack" (later changed to "Heavenly Blues" by Peter Fonda), but insisted that a stunt double do his motorcycle riding, so Corman replaced him with Fonda, who was originally cast as "Loser".', u'Actress Laura Dern (daughter of Bruce Dern and Diane Ladd) was conceived during the movie shoot. Growing up, she sometimes showed people who asked about her parents a still of them in their biker outfits.', u'The quote "we wanna get loaded . . . " was used by Mudhoney as the intro to their song "In \'n\' Out of Grace" from the 1988 EP "Superfuzz Bigmuff" and Primal Scream did the same thing with a slightly shorter version on their song "Loaded", which was first released in 1991 on the album "Screamadelica".', u'The film was initially refused a UK cinema certificate in 1966 and eventually passed with cuts in 1972. Later video and DVD releases were fully uncut.', u'Around the time of shooting the funeral for "\'Loser" outside of the church at North Argyle, Bruce Dern was assaulted and beaten by two real Hell\'s Angels; Dern tried to explain he was in a movie, but the bikers didn\'t believe him and knocked him out cold on the sidewalk. Later, Bruce said: "It was, like, hey, I\'m not even alive in the movie, I\'m dead, and they\'re STILL beating on me . . ."']

taglines: [u"Suspensful desert pursuit in the 'High Noon' tradition."]
trivia: [u'Monte Hellman got the idea to cast Millie Perkins, Warren Oates and Will Hutchins in the lead roles while shopping in a Los Angeles book store.', u"In Warren Oates' biography he says that he had a crush on co-star Millie Perkins.", u'Shot in three weeks.', u'$10,000 of the budget was spent on the salaries for the horse wranglers, who along with the cast were the only union element in the picture.', u'Very little was accomplished in the first two days of shooting because of near constant rain, which caused severe flooding in the areas that were chosen as key locations. Monte Hellman estimates that $5,000 of the slight budget was wasted on these two days.', u'Shot back to back with Ride in the Whirlwind (1966).', u'Millie Perkins wore a hairpiece in this film.', u'Sterling Hayden was briefly considered to play Willett Gashade.', u"Millie Perkins was Monte Hellman's next-door neighbor at the time this film was made.", u'First shown at the Montreal Film Festival in Canada.', u'Cinematographer Gregory Sandor shot the bulk of this film using natural light.', u'"The Epitaph" was the unfilmed script that Jack Nicholson wrote with Monte Hellman. Reputedly based partly on Nicholson\'s relationship with his wife Sandra Knight, the script dealt with the theme of abortion, which producer Roger Corman felt was a no-no at that time.', u'Ten pages were eliminated from the script right before the filming of this movie.', u'U.S. distribution rights were purchased by the Walter Reade Organization; no other domestic distributor had expressed any interest in the film. Walter Reade decided to bypass a theatrical release, and it was sold directly to television.', u'Filmed in 1965.']
